author: Jeff Parsons
title: New poisonous spider species is hungry for love: experts reveal male sinks fangs into female before mating
text:
Four new species of huntsman spider have been discovered living in Namibia and other parts of southern Africa.
Researchers believe some of the new genus have a bizarre courtship ritual where the males bite the females before mating with them.
Of the four new species , May bruno, May ansie, May rudy and May norm, arachnologists spotted paired scars on the back of May bruno and May norm.
Senckenberg/Kunz May Bruno Spider from Witsand, South Africa
The scars only appeared on the females - leading the experts to believe they were inflicted as part of courtship.
"It is quite possible that these injuries were sustained during mating," said Dr Peter Jäger, who co-authored the report on the new spiders in the journal African Invertebrates.
"We were unable to find these marks on the males of the "Love Bite Spider"," he said, noting that the distance between the scars is the same as that between the two fangs of the male spider.
Peter Jäger Dark claw tufts of setae for the May bruno spider
"The scars could be part of a pre-copulatory courtship behavior," Dr. Jäger said.
Each of the new species have hairy feet to help them run on the desert and the largest, May bruno, has a body about half an inch long and legs than span three inches.
John Leroy These spiders have hairy feet for running across the desert
Like other huntsman spiders, the May genus doesn't spin a web to catch prey, but rather attacks it directly - hiding in old tree bark, rotting leaves and other crevices.
